text:
PRIMO solidified my goal
of wanting to get a PhD.

And it definitely
expanded my ideas
of what research can look like.

I feel like I've been
able to see the world
in a new lens because of PRIMO.

It has definitely
changed my stance

on what I want to
do in my future.

It's one of those
life-changing summers.

By the end of the
summer, I very much

felt like research was going
to be integral to any career I
decided to descend upon.

Without curiosity,
there is no way forward.

Like, you're not
going to move forward

unless there is this intrinsic
drive to figure something out
that you didn't know previously.

And I don't ever
want it to go away

because I think that's where
most of my joy comes from.

I think the biggest thing
that I got out of PRIMO,
there's really so many things.

I think coming to HBS
and working with my team

has been really helpful
in just getting a wider,

more diverse view of what
research does look like,
and what it can look like.

And I think that really
affirmed the fact that this is
what I want to do for my life.

It's just been, like, the
opportunity of a lifetime.
Truly.

I was previously intimidated
by a lot of academic spheres.

I actually previously
thought that maybe research

wasn't for me, but being
immersed in this world, where

there were academics
and scholars

and being able to
actually, physically

be here at Harvard
Business School

made it such an
exciting opportunity.

I remember, I was in my
kitchen with my roommates,

and I got an email with a
title, like, PRIMO interview.

And I was like, Harvard
wants to interview me.

And I just like-- we all
just started screaming.

These are some of
the most helpful,

wanting you to
succeed communities
you'll ever be a part of.

People that were just
really championing
you and your success.

Coming from a small
liberal arts school,

it was actually surprising
in a very pleasant way

to see how professors are just
as eager to get to know you.

I expected everyone being
off doing their own thing,

but came here and
everyone's working together.

I think, in math or
like hard sciences,

there's always a really
well-defined problem
you're trying to solve.

With more
business-oriented research,

there are also some variables
that you can't control for.

And that means that over
the course of your research,

you may find the question itself
that you're trying to answer
is going to change.

But that's really what the
beauty of the research is.

I think one of my
favorite things

was how diverse our
group was last year.

Different races and ethnicities
and different backgrounds.

People studying psychology
and neuroscience,

not just economics and math,
like I had been studying.

People who are rising
sophomores, rising juniors,

and people like
myself, rising seniors,

all being able to
do similar things.

It had cultivated a lot of
interesting conversations

that led me to places that I
have never even thought about.

It's the social connections
that I've established.

And honestly, I really,
really look forward

to maintaining those
relationships in the years
to come.

I loved getting to
know all of them.

They're such brilliant
people, really personable.

The combination of
that plus getting

to do all the fun stuff,
kayaking with the crew,
going out to eat.

There was insurmountable level
of bonding between all of us
because we were just together.
We were different.
We were all new to Boston.

It was just-- it
was really great.
100% apply.
I am so glad that I did.

PRIMO is like full of surprises
and just like, excitement,

curiosity, and people
who really, really care,

from the doctoral staff to
all the lecturers who come in,
all the PRIMO Fellows.
It's just such a good community.

And I'm so glad that this was
my introduction to academia.

As long as you're willing
to learn, as long as you're

willing to be immersed
in what you're doing,
you are going to succeed.

Because the main
point of research

is to ask better and
better questions each time.

I've only gotten as
far as I've gotten

in my academic and
professional career

because I've taken
a bet on myself.

So I would just
encourage anyone,

step out of your own way and
really give yourself a shot.
Shoot for the stars.
Maybe you'll land on the moon.

Ultimately, I just kind of
broadened my scope after PRIMO

and realized, I didn't
really have a dream job,
but I had a dream impact.
